resumen:
El regreso de Donald Trump a la Casa Blanca y su guerra comercial han sacudido el mundo, generando un nuevo escenario que abre oportunidades para América Latina y Europa.

Nuria Vilanova, presidenta del Consejo Empresarial Alianza para Iberoamérica (CEAPI), destaca que Trump es un catalizador para buscar nuevas alianzas en busca de una mayor autonomía e independencia comercial y económica.

Sergio Díaz-Granados, presidente del Banco de Desarrollo de América Latina y el Caribe (CAF), señala un cambio profundo en el mundo, con reglas propias en lugar de reglas multilaterales.

Los aranceles de EE UU han generado preocupación, pero no miedo, entre los empresarios reunidos en Sevilla.

Omar Santos, dueño del grupo Trinity, y Stanley Motta, propietario de Copa Airlines, expresan que están a la espera de ver cómo queda el tablero.

Jordi Hereu, ministro de Industria y Turismo, subraya la oportunidad para España como puerta de entrada a Europa y para la UE.

En la última década el mundo se ha vuelto multipolar, con la presencia de China en los países latinoamericanos.

La firma del acuerdo UE-Mercosur está llamada a revitalizar las relaciones transatlánticas.

Sergio Díaz-Granados, presidente del CAF, pronuncia que si logran el acuerdo de Mercosur tendrán el área comercial más grande del mundo con más de 1.100 millones de personas y un área que aglutina el 25% del PIB mundial.

Arancha González Laya, exministra de Exteriores de España, apunta que “Iberoamérica tiene el antídoto ante la volatilidad económica y la volatilidad política. Es importante que Europa suscriba el acuerdo de Mercosur”.

El FMI calcula un crecimiento para América Latina y el Caribe del 2,0% en 2025, antes de repuntar al 2,4% en 2026, el doble que la Unión Europea.

La inversión extranjera directa emitida por América Latina alcanzó en 2024 los 53.035 millones de dólares, lo que representa un crecimiento interanual del 50%.

La UE es el tercer socio comercial más importante de América Latina.

El comercio total entre la UE y la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (CELAC) en bienes y servicios ascendió a 395.000 millones de euros, lo que supone un aumento del 45% en la última década.

Manuel Contreras, presidente de la constructora andaluza Azvi, explica que países como Alemania, Bélgica o Francia han visto que el único sitio donde tienen capacidad de crecer y el único continente que realmente ofrece esa oportunidad es América.

CEAPI apunta a cinco grandes sectores donde Latinoamérica ofrece grandes oportunidades: minería, energía y agua, agricultura, turismo y educación.

Roque Benavides, presidente del grupo peruano Buenaventura, advierte de que para la transición energética se necesitará más cobre.

Carlos Diez Rosillo, ex subsecretario adjunto de defensa en la anterior administración de Trump, anima a las empresas latinoamericanas a aliarse con compañías estadounidenses para captar inversión y relocalizar fábricas al sur de la frontera de EEUU.

En noviembre se celebrará en Colombia la cumbre de Santa Marta para impulsar la relación UE-CELAC.

La UE presentó la agenda de inversiones Global Gateway para movilizar 45.000 millones de euros hasta 2027.

title: Aluminium producers in the US win from Trump's tariffs
content: Century Aluminum, the largest primary aluminium producer in the U.S., and top recycler Matalco will be among the big winners from President Donald Trump's higher tariffs on imports of the metal as ...
resumen: Century Aluminum, the largest primary aluminium producer in the U.S., and top recycler Matalco will be among the big winners from President Donald Trump's higher tariffs on imports of the metal. Trump hiked the tariffs to 50%, from 25%, from June 4. The Midwest premium hit a record 62.5 U.S. cents a lb, or $1,377 a metric ton, on Friday. Since Trump was elected for his second term in November, it has surged nearly 190%. Consultancy Harbor Aluminum said the premium would have to rise to 70 cents a lb, or $1,543 a ton, to fully reflect the 50% tariff. Century (CENX.O), in which London-listed miner Glencore (GLEN.L) is the top shareholder with a stake of more than 40%, declined to comment beyond a statement it issued last week, in which it welcomed the 50% tariff. Century produced 690,000 metric tons of aluminium last year. Miner Rio Tinto (RIO.L), (RIO.AX), which owns a 50% stake in Matalco, declined to comment, speaking on behalf of the U.S. company, which produced 528,000 tons of recycled or secondary aluminium last year. U.S. imports of scrap aluminium remain free of tariffs. Alcoa (AA.N), one of the world's largest aluminium producers, said its U.S. smelters would also benefit from the tariffs, and that its active production capacity in the United States totalled 291,000 tons. Alcoa's global aluminium output was 2.215 million tons last year. Constellium, which has a capacity to recycle 360,000 tons of aluminium annually in the United States, said it supported the original 25% tariff. The U.S. relies on imports of large amounts of unwrought aluminium and alloys - more than 3.9 million tons last year, according to U.S. government data. The U.S. produced more than four million tons of aluminium last year, most of it recycled material, according U.S. Geological Survey. U.S. scrap aluminium imports rose more than 30% to 201,968 tons in the first quarter of this year from the same period in 2024. LME aluminium is trading around $2,500 a ton, while the duty-paid premium in Europe has dropped more than 50% to $170 a ton since January.

title: Tell Me How This Trade War Ends
content: From 2019 to 2021, first in the Trump administration and then in the Biden administration, she was Deputy Assistant U.S. Trade Representative for Investment. Geoffrey Gertz is a Senior Fellow in the ...
resumen:
On April 2, President Donald Trump announced a new program of tariffs intended to rebalance U.S. trade. Trump's tariff rates were high, triggering a stock market selloff and diplomatic outrage. After a week of backlash, the president announced a 90-day pause on most tariffs. U.S. court rulings questioning the legality of the president’s tariffs have added further uncertainty.

The Trump administration’s trade policy has caused harm, slowing growth and raising prices. Distrust of free trade has been rising in both political parties in the United States. Governments around the world are more and more willing to intervene in their economies to safeguard national interests. The U.S.-led global trading order, constructed over eight decades following World War II, has frayed.

Instead of trying to turn back time, actors should push the administration to usher in the needed transformation of the global trading order. Disruptive tariffs can create an opportunity. The United States retains deep-rooted structural advantages that give it the power to lead a new trade effort. Washington can leverage its trade wars to achieve a productive restructuring of the international economic system.

The Trump administration must build a new set of rules and norms that facilitate integration among like-minded states and that disentangle them from adversarial ones, especially China.

The current trading system prioritizes nondiscrimination and the “most favored nation” principle. But economic and national security concerns differ by trading partner. Increasing geopolitical competition has compelled more and more countries to impose export controls, sanctions, and other economic restrictions on trading partners.

Trump has turned the United States into a revisionist power. There is still an opportunity to wrest a positive outcome from the current tumult. In March, the Center for a New American Security ran a simulation of a trade war to examine how foreign governments might respond to sharply increased U.S. tariffs. By the end of the game, the U.S. team had unexpectedly succeeded in laying the foundation for a highly integrated democratic trading bloc that shut out China.

To achieve a positive outcome, Trump will have to prioritize good-faith trade negotiations and tamp down the more chaotic aspects of his trade policy.

Washington must use tariffs as leverage in pursuit of clear and achievable trade objectives. The administration has offered an array of rationales for the tariffs. The administration was always going to have to prioritize its aims; the sooner it does so, the better.

The Trump administration can still improve U.S. credibility by bringing more order and predictability into the trade policymaking process. The administration could use instruments such as Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974, which addresses unfair trade practices, and Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act, which allows the United States to impose tariffs or take other remedial actions on national security grounds. Washington must also clarify what it expects of allies.

Trump has demonstrated little interest in adopting a more deliberate, methodical approach to negotiations or to recalibrating his means to meet more achievable ends.

The United States could advance a more nakedly transactional approach in its international economic relations, eschewing any rules or shared norms that might constrain U.S. action.

Having used tariffs to shake trading partners out of their complacency, the United States can work with these countries to negotiate a reset of the trading system—one that preserves many of the advantages of the old system while rectifying its shortcomings. The starting point should be relaxing the principle of nondiscrimination and accepting that trade policy will differentiate among trade partners and allow democracies to favor one another.

The United States should continue to trade with China in low-end manufacturing, agriculture, and a handful of other areas. But in more strategic sectors, such as chips and pharmaceuticals, Trump should prioritize “de-risking” from China. Washington should make significant investments in domestic manufacturing and research and design, coordinating with other major economies wherever possible.

Trump should aim for a future order made up of the following concentric circles: deep economic and security integration for close allies and partners; predictable, rules-based exchange among most countries; and careful de-risking from competitors. Washington should seek to establish legally binding commitments with its close partners that provide the clarity, consistency, and credibility that businesses and governments require.

title: Overcoming the geopolitics of overcapacity through cooperation
content: Multilateral reform is needed to counteract prevailing narratives of Chinese overcapacity and restore confidence in the rules-based trade system.
resumen:
Overcapacity in Chinese industries like steel, EVs and solar panels has become a flashpoint in global trade, especially in US–China tensions. While often framed as unfair trade practices due to subsidies and low-priced exports, these concerns reflect deeper strategic fears about China’s rise in key sectors. Lasting solutions require multilateral cooperation and WTO reform to restore trade stability.

‘Overcapacity’ has become a buzzword in trade policy discussions, especially amid US–China trade tensions. Overcapacity is a global issue that requires multilateral cooperation and reform to address structural imbalances and restore trade stability.

The ‘China shock’ that followed China’s 2001 accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) led to massive influxes of Chinese exports into the United States and other economies.

In 2024, then treasury secretary Janet Yellen and under secretary for international affairs Jay Shambaugh criticised China for creating excessive production capacity through industrial policies and subsidies across sectors like steel, solar panels and electric vehicles (EVs).

Governments’ key concerns are overcapacity’s underlying causes and spillover effects via artificially low-priced exports, widely labelled as ‘unfair trade practices’, causing injury to domestic industries.

The Biden administration levied high tariffs on Chinese steel, EV and solar cells exports. US President Donald Trump’s 2025 tariffs against China target non-market policies and unfair trade practices to revitalise US manufacturing competitiveness and global leadership.

China’s innovation and sustainability-oriented development strategies have generated selective industrial policies whose spillover effects may become increasingly concentrated in strategic and emerging sectors like advanced manufacturing and frontier technologies.

Studies have found no compelling evidence of an economy-wide overcapacity problem in China and argue that China needs time to make necessary industrial adjustments given declining domestic consumption. China has contended that other countries also have overcapacity issues in certain sectors. China has also sought to reduce capacity in traditional industries like steel to facilitate industrial restructuring and sustainable development while rolling out plans to boost domestic consumption.

Criticisms of overcapacity serve more political and strategic goals than purely economic interests. China’s industrial overcapacity poses challenges for trading partners as it represents a quest for global leadership in key and emerging industries and critical supply chains.

China dominates global EV production and sales, alarming trading partners. The United States, European Union, Canada and Brazil have imposed high tariffs on Chinese EV imports.

China remains the world’s top producer and exporter of steel, solar panels and EVs despite facing high antidumping and countervailing tariffs and other restrictive measures for decades. In some cases, Chinese exporters absorbed the price increases resulting from tariffs. In other cases, Chinese firms redirected exports to or via third countries or relocated production overseas, an approach known as ‘tariff circumvention’.

Many economies have developed so-called anti-circumvention instruments which extend existing tariffs to the same or similar Chinese exports from third-country markets. Beijing also sought to counteract foreign sanctions through WTO litigation and retaliatory measures.

Escalating trade restrictions — particularly Trump’s 2025 tariffs — have accelerated China’s pivot towards domestic economic rebalancing. China has rolled out measures to redirect excess industrial output towards the domestic market. These include expanded consumer subsidies for durable goods, tax incentives for firms repurposing export production for domestic sale and initiatives to bolster rural and middle-class spending.

Actions against Chinese overcapacity exacerbate global trade uncertainty, distort commercial decisions and disrupt global supply chains. US tariffs against China can redirect Chinese exports to other markets, ratcheting up overcapacity pressure on the rest of the world.

It is time for governments to cooperate. The US–China deal reached on 12 May 2025 to scale back a significant portion of their respective tariffs and establish a mechanism for cooperative talks marks a step in the right direction.

Overcapacity is a global issue that cannot be resolved unilaterally or bilaterally. It requires multilateral reforms of the rules-based international trading regime, with the WTO at its core. Overcapacity requires a detailed examination now with a particular focus on overcapacity’s underlying drivers like persistent demand shortfalls and industrial subsidies.

title: India could cut tariffs for all except China
content: India has been in Trump’s crosshairs since the start of his second term. On April 2, he proposed a 26 per cent reciprocal tariff on Indian imports, later withdrawn, but imposed a 10 per cent baseline ...
resumen: India should consider cutting tariffs for all trading partners except China. Global trade is shifting rapidly, with the US and China experiencing tariff stand-offs. The US imposed a 10 per cent baseline tariff on nearly all countries, including India. India has largely avoided retaliating against US tariffs, except for plans to counter US duties on Indian steel and aluminum. India should adopt a proactive, broad-based strategy, including across-the-board tariff cuts. India's average MFN tariffs are higher than many peers. Tariff cuts improve resource allocation and boost overall economic welfare. China may target India regardless of tariff cuts due to weak global demand and its own strained economy. In 2024, 25 of 31 ongoing anti-dumping investigations and 24 of 29 concluded cases involved Chinese firms. A more strategic response to Chinese dumping is to cut tariffs for all trading partners, except China. Global trade simulations were run using the GTAP dataset and model. With a 25 per cent across-the-board tariff cut, India could gain $54 billion, boost GDP by 2.6 per cent, sectoral output by 2.8 per cent, and exports by 4.3 per cent. Imports from China would surge by 8.6 per cent. Under the second policy, where tariffs on China remain unchanged, GDP, welfare, and output remain strong, domestic demand doubles, and exports stay positive. Ganesh-Kumar and Jaiswal are the authors.

title: The EU can play it cool with Trump’s trade threats
content: Other governments have so far taken three main approaches to dealing with Donald Trump’s trade threats. China hit back hard at the U.S. president’s tariffs and got him to back down partly. Canada also ...
resumen:
Other governments have so far taken three main approaches to dealing with Donald Trump’s trade threats. China hit back hard at the U.S. president’s tariffs and got him to back down partly. Canada also retaliated and avoided some of the pain Trump inflicted on other countries. Meanwhile, Britain cut a quick deal that favoured the United States. None of these is a model for the European Union.

The EU is not China. Though its bilateral goods trade with the United States last year was worth 70% more than between the U.S. and the People’s Republic, the EU is not an autocracy that can outpunch Trump. If it antagonises the U.S. president, he might up the stakes by pulling the rug from under Ukraine and undermining the EU’s defences. American hard power gives it what geopolitical strategists call “escalation dominance”.

The EU is not Canada either. Ottawa was able to hang tough because its people were infuriated that Trump was trying to blackmail Canada into becoming part of the United States. While anti-Trump sentiment is high in the EU, politicians who are sympathetic to him, such as Poland’s new president, can still get elected.

The EU is not the United Kingdom. Both are at risk from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. But the EU trades seven times more goods with the United States than Britain does - so Washington has more to lose if economic relations break down.

There is another way for the EU to handle Trump’s threats: play it cool. It involves neither escalating the conflict nor accepting a bad deal. It means being open to a good agreement if the U.S. lowers its demands, but willing to play the long game if it does not.

One reason to buy time is to help Kyiv. The longer the EU has to prepare its own support package for Ukraine, which should include getting it a lot of cash, the less the damage if Trump ultimately cuts off all U.S. aid to the country.

The president’s own vulnerabilities may also increase over time. Just look at the spectacular end of his alliance with Tesla boss Elon Musk. The fragile U.S. trade truce with China may break down causing more financial turmoil, making Trump less keen to pick a fight with the EU. If the Supreme Court stops him using emergency powers to impose tariffs, his negotiating position will be weaker. And tariffs could hurt the U.S. more than its supposed victims, by pushing up inflation and crimping growth.

Trump has zig-zagged in his trade threats and actions against the EU. The current state of play is that there are 50% tariffs on U.S. imports of steel and aluminium from the bloc, a 25% tariff on cars and 10% so-called reciprocal tariffs on most other goods.

The U.S. president has threatened to jack up these reciprocal tariffs to 50% if there is no deal by July 9. He is also looking at more “sectoral tariffs”, including on pharmaceuticals and semiconductors.

While the EU has complained to the World Trade Organization (WTO), it has delayed its own retaliation. Its negotiators accept that they are unlikely to overturn the reciprocal tariffs, the Financial Times has reported.

The bloc still aims to avoid the sectoral ones. Those on cars and any on pharmaceuticals would hurt it the most. It has dangled the possibility of buying more U.S. equipment and natural gas to get a deal.

An agreement on those lines could be good for the EU. It needs to beef up its defences and eliminate its purchases of Russian gas. While it would be best to have its own arms and energy supplies, buying more from the U.S. makes sense as an interim measure. An important nuance, though, is that the EU should reserve the right to take action against the reciprocal tariffs after the WTO issues its verdict, says Ignacio Garcia Bercero, a former senior EU trade official.

Such a pact would involve quite a climbdown by Trump. True, arms and gas purchases would narrow the U.S. goods deficit with the EU, which was $236 billion last year. But his administration has a host of other complaints including the bloc’s value-added tax and food safety standards as well the digital taxes that some of its members impose on tech giants. It is hard to see the bloc agreeing anything in those areas, says Simon Evenett, professor of geopolitics and strategy at IMD.

Although the U.S. side described last week’s trade talks with the EU as “very constructive”, discussions could easily break down. The question then is how the bloc would react if Trump imposed higher reciprocal tariffs.

The EU has so far imposed no countermeasures. Though it has agreed to tax 21 billion euros of U.S. imports in response to the steel and aluminium tariffs, it has delayed these until July 14 to try to get a deal. The European Commission, its executive arm, is also consulting on taxing a further 95 billion euros of U.S. imports in response to the car tariffs and the reciprocal ones. But added together, these tit-for-tat measures would be equivalent to only a third of the 379 billion euros of EU imports subject to Trump’s tariffs.

Some analysts think the bloc needs to be tougher. One idea is to crack down on American services, where the U.S. had a 109 billion euro surplus with the EU in 2023. Another is to activate its “anti-coercion instrument”, which would allow retaliation against U.S. companies operating in the bloc. Yet another is to threaten to ban exports of critical goods, such as the lithographic equipment necessary to make semiconductors.

For now, the EU should keep its cool. It should not kid itself that it is stronger or more united than it is. It should remember that Trump may get weaker with time. And it should never forget Ukraine.

title: US aluminium tariffs threaten scrap clash with European Union
content: U.S. President Donald Trump's move to double tariffs on aluminium imports heightens the risk of a full-blown scrap war with the European Union.
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump's move to double tariffs on aluminium imports heightens the risk of a full-blown scrap war with the European Union. Aluminium scrap is explicitly excluded on the grounds it constitutes a key raw material for U.S. manufacturers. The Trump administration's decision to lift aluminium tariffs to 25% effective the start of March has already caused U.S. imports of recyclable material to rise. This week's doubling of the tariff rate to 50% could turn the import flow into a flood. The European Union, which is mulling export duties on aluminium recyclables to stop what it terms "scrap leakage", is coming under pressure to move sooner rather than later. The U.S. Midwest aluminium premium has rocketed to a record $1,325 per metric ton after Wednesday's doubling-down on import tariffs. That's the price U.S. buyers will pay over and above the international price traded on the London Metal Exchange (LME), currently $2,430 per ton for cash metal. U.S. consumers of aluminium goods will ultimately foot the bill but mid-stream processors are likely to do well. U.S. imports of aluminium recyclable materials jumped to over 80,000 tons in March, the highest monthly volume since 2022. There were sharp increases in supply from Canada and Mexico. Exports from EU countries to the United States spiked in the first quarter of the year. The EU is facing a "full-blown scrap crisis". Director General Paul Voss called on the European Commission to immediately impose a corresponding duty on scrap exports to the United States. A March "Action Plan" for both the aluminium and steel sectors promised a decision by the third quarter of this year on suitable trade measures, including reciprocal export tariffs on countries "that apply unfair subsidies" to their recycling industries. Caught in the middle of this tug-of-war is China, the world's largest aluminium scrap buyer. The country has imported 1.8 million tons in each of the last two years. Beijing last year relaxed the purity rules on imports of both copper and aluminium scrap to encourage greater domestic recycling.

title: Trump's trade war is raising money for the government, but at whose expense?
content: Tariff collections are up sharply in the last 2 months. Congressional forecasters say tariffs could help reduce the federal debt, but they'll also lead to higher inflation and slower economic growth.
resumen: President Trump's tariffs are helping the government's bottom line. The federal government collected $68.9 billion in tariffs and excise taxes during the first five months of the year, according to Treasury Department data collected by the Bipartisan Policy Center. This is a 78% increase from the same period a year ago. Much of the additional revenue came in April and May, after Trump imposed tariffs of at least 10% on nearly everything the U.S. buys from other countries. The tariffs are mostly being paid by American businesses and families. Patrick Allen, a Columbus, Ohio-based importer who sells French wine throughout the country, says, "It's a tax on the backs of people who are importing either raw materials or, in my case, wine." The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projected that if Trump's tariffs were to remain in place for a full decade, they could shave $2.8 trillion off the federal debt. The CBO also acknowledged that the tariffs will result in higher inflation this year and next, as well as slower economic growth. A survey from the Institute for Supply Management suggests tariffs are a substantial drag on the manufacturing sector, which cut 8,000 jobs last month. For importers like Allen, tariffs are also a cash-flow challenge. Trump initially announced a 20% tariff on imports from the European Union. He later reduced that to 10% for a 90-day period, but has since threatened to increase the tariff on European goods to 50%. Customs broker Margie Shapiro used to pay tariffs in advance for her clients and collect the money later, which was possible when the average tariff rate was under 3%.

title: Trump long disparaged Haitians before new travel ban
content: When Trump included Haiti in a list of countries on which he was imposing a near-total travel ban, some saw a culmination of a long campaign against the population.
resumen: En una reunión a principios de 2018, el presidente Trump usó un expletivo al referirse a Haití y a las naciones africanas. Trump dijo que debería haber más inmigrantes de países como Noruega. Haití fue incluido en una lista de países a los que Trump impuso una prohibición de viaje casi total. La representante de Boston, Ayanna Pressley, dijo que Donald Trump ha sido muy consistente en su racismo anti-negro, tanto a nivel nacional como mundial, y que tiene un largo historial de retórica y políticas dañinas y ofensivas hacia Haití y su gente. El representante demócrata de Florida, Maxwell Frost, de ascendencia haitiana, se hizo eco del comentario de Pressley de que la prohibición de viajar está "arraigada en la intolerancia". La Casa Blanca calificó las afirmaciones de Pressley de "perezosas, infundadas y simplemente falsas". Haití es uno de los 12 países que se enfrentan a una prohibición casi total de viajar a Estados Unidos según la nueva orden de Trump, que cita la incapacidad de examinar a los inmigrantes en busca de riesgos para la seguridad nacional y una alta tasa de personas que se quedan más tiempo del permitido por sus visados como justificación de la medida. Hay excepciones limitadas, incluidos los titulares de visados actuales, los residentes permanentes, los ciudadanos con doble nacionalidad, los equipos deportivos y ciertos familiares directos de los residentes estadounidenses. Otros países afectados son Afganistán, Irán, Libia, Somalia y Yemen. La medida sigue a otras acciones de la administración Trump que han tenido un impacto en la comunidad haitiana en Estados Unidos, incluido el fin anticipado de las protecciones del Estatus de Protección Temporal para unos 260.000 haitianos. La administración también está revocando el estatus de otros 200.000 haitianos a los que se les permitió temporalmente entrar en Estados Unidos en virtud de un programa de Biden para inmigrantes de países específicos, incluidos Cuba, Venezuela y Nicaragua, conocido como el programa CHNV. Ambos son objeto de litigio, aunque el Tribunal Supremo permitió recientemente a la administración Trump deportar a los participantes en el programa CHNV a medida que el caso continúa a través del proceso de apelación. Estados Unidos concedió por primera vez protección contra la deportación a los migrantes haitianos después del terremoto de 2010 que devastó el país. Desde entonces, una serie de desastres naturales y conflictos políticos han empeorado las condiciones. Hoy en día, la violencia de las bandas, la delincuencia y la inestabilidad son rampantes en la isla. Massachusetts tiene la tercera población más grande de haitianos en Estados Unidos, incluidos unos 15.000 que tenían TPS, según la fiscal general Andrea Campbell, que forma parte de una coalición que impugna las rescisiones en los tribunales. El senador de Illinois Dick Durbin, que fue el único demócrata en la reunión de 2018 con los ahora infames comentarios de Trump, dijo que no entiende por qué Haití parece irritar al presidente como lo hace. El representante republicano Mario Diaz-Balart, que ha apoyado políticas pro-inmigración en el pasado, también estuvo en esa reunión de 2018. El ex representante republicano de Florida Carlos Curbelo, que formó parte de las negociaciones sobre inmigración en 2018 que precedieron a la reunión, dijo que Trump parece preferir a los inmigrantes de "cuello blanco" o a aquellos que Trump percibe que han sido reclutados o que tienen recursos suficientes para venir aquí. Pressley está convencida de que el enfoque de Trump hacia los haitianos es un esfuerzo concertado.

title: Opinion: Tariffs make the world poorer and more perilous
content: President Trump’s on-again-off-again tariffs have disrupted the global trading system and caused whiplash for businesses and consumers. He has vacillated mightily, announcing tariffs on imports from ...
resumen:
President Trump’s tariffs have disrupted the global trading system and caused whiplash for businesses and consumers. Raising tariffs undermines trade and weakens economic links that stabilize international relations. Mr. Trump has undercut the entire international rules-based order, including ignoring the rules of the World Trade Organization, hindering its work and threatening to abandon it.

Denying low-income countries the opportunity to develop their economies through trade could lead to a surge of migrants. A retreat from free trade will hurt consumers worldwide through higher prices and more limited choices.

The Trump tariffs will make the world a poorer and more perilous place.

International commerce is already shifting in ways that can deepen geopolitical fissures.

Trade has come to be seen as a zero-sum game.

Middle-power countries such as India now recognize that even U.S. friendship may not protect them from tariffs. Even longstanding U.S. allies such as Britain and the European Union were not spared from tariffs.

Falling trade barriers and declining transportation costs had led corporations to build lean supply chains threaded through multiple countries. This approach drove down prices for consumers, increased product choices, helped spread new technologies and promoted innovation.

Businesses worldwide were already dealing with disruptions caused by climate change and geopolitical flare-ups, including the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Now they have to face the possibility of a trade war resulting from retaliatory tariffs and from many countries’ concerns about becoming dumping grounds for Chinese exports.

Businesses are being forced to focus on resilience of their supply chains rather than efficiency. Companies are resorting to reshoring and “friend-shoring”.

The viability of rerouting output and restructuring supply chains from China through Vietnam and India has fallen prey to proposed tariffs. Canada and Mexico have not escaped either.

China took advantage of World Trade Organization rules to gain access to other countries’ markets for its exports while limiting access to its own markets. China has also used extensive subsidies and other measures, including forced technology transfers from foreign companies.

Smashing the rules-based global trade system will only create anarchy.

For customers around the world, the retreat from unfettered trade will mean higher prices. For many low-income countries trying to follow the path of manufacturing-led development, the traditional route to building a robust middle class is disappearing. A world with less trade and more uncertainty will be a less prosperous one. All countries, including the United States, will feel the pain.

Eswar Prasad is a professor of trade policy in the Dyson School at Cornell University and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

title: Confían mercados en México: Claudia Sheinbaum
content: Los inversionistas y los mercados tienen confianza en México. La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, presumió ayer una serie de indicadores económicos positivos, como la mejor cotización del peso ...
resumen: Los inversionistas y los mercados tienen confianza en México. La presidenta de México, Claudia Sheinbaum, presumió una serie de indicadores económicos positivos, como la mejor cotización del peso que abrió en su mejor nivel en todo lo que va de 2025. Sheinbaum destacó la confianza en el país de los mercados pese las tensiones globales, en especial por la guerra comercial desatada por Estados Unidos. Sheinbaum dijo: “Para todos los pesimistas vamos a darles optimismo el día de hoy”. Sheinbaum mencionó que es falso que por la Reforma Judicial y la elección de jueces, los mercados perderían confianza en México como alegaban los comentócratas. Durante la conferencia mañanera, en Palacio Nacional, también subrayó algunos avances logrados durante la administración de su antecesor, Andrés Manuel López Obrador (2018-2024), como la reducción de la pobreza. Sheinbaum dijo: “Once millones de mexicanos han salido de la pobreza en los últimos años” al citar como fuente al Banco Mundial, que presentó un informe en su Plataforma de Pobreza y Desigualdad. Destacó que una reciente revisión del Banco Mundial sobre la disminución de la pobreza en el país, concluyó que 11 millones de mexicanos salieron de la pobreza entre 2018 y 2024, casi 2 millones más de los reportados inicialmente. Sheinbaum subrayó: “Es decir, ya no son 9.5 (millones de mexicanos que salieron de la pobreza), sino 11 millones, dicho por el Banco Mundial. Eso es para levantar el ánimo”. Sheinbaum abrió su conferencia con indicadores positivos económicos, entre ellos la cotización del peso frente al dólar que abrió el día en 19.14 unidades por dólar, su mejor nivel en todo lo que va de 2025. Sheinbaum agregó: “Es decir, hay confianza en nuestro país (… ) aun con todas las dificultades económicas internacionales”, señalando que tanto la inversión pública como privada continúan creciendo. Sheinbaum citó además declaraciones del secretario de Comercio de Estados Unidos, quien expresó la intención de “reimaginar la relación con México para hacer negocios juntos”. Las previsiones de analistas y diversos organismos internacionales advierten que la economía de México enfrenta una marcada desaceleración este año. El Banco de México (Banxico) rebajó en mayo sus pronósticos de crecimiento para la economía mexicana, al estimar un crecimiento del 0.1 por ciento en 2025, frente al 0.6 por ciento previsto hace tres meses, y por debajo del 1.2 por ciento de expansión registrada en 2024.

title: President Trump flexes emergency powers in his second term
content: Whether it’s leveling punishing tariffs, deploying troops to the border or sidelining environmental regulations, President Trump has relied on rules and laws intended only for use in extraordinary ...
resumen: President Donald Trump is using emergency powers in his second term. He is harnessing emergency powers more than his predecessors, relying on rules and laws intended for extraordinary circumstances. An analysis by The Associated Press shows that 30 of Trump’s 150 executive orders have cited some kind of emergency power or authority. Trump is using emergency powers to supplant Congress’ authority and advance his agenda. Ilya Somin is representing five U.S. businesses who sued the administration, claiming they were harmed by Trump’s so-called “Liberation Day” tariffs. The businesses convinced a federal trade court that Trump overstepped his authority by claiming an economic emergency to impose the tariffs. An appeals court has paused that ruling. Elizabeth Goitein, senior director of the Brennan Center’s Liberty and National Security Program, said that there is growing concern that Trump is pressing the limits when the U.S. is not facing the kinds of threats such actions are meant to address. Rep. Don Bacon, R-Neb., believes the courts would ultimately rule against Trump in his efforts to single-handedly shape trade policy. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Trump is justified in aggressively using his authority. Trump has most frequently cited the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEEPA, to justify slapping tariffs on imports. The law, enacted in 1977, was intended to limit some of the expansive authority that had been granted to the presidency decades earlier. The AP found that Trump has invoked the law 21 times in presidential orders and memoranda. President George W. Bush invoked the law 14 times in his first term. Barack Obama invoked the act 21 times during his first term. The Trump administration has also deployed the Alien Enemies Act to justify deporting Venezuelan migrants to other countries. There are 150 legal powers that can only be accessed after declaring an emergency. John Yoo, who as a Justice Department official under George W. Bush helped expand the use of presidential authorities, said Trump has elevated it to another level. Vice President JD Vance predicted the administration would prevail in the court fight over tariff policy. Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn., argued that, historically, leaders relying on emergency declarations has been a “path toward autocracy and suppression.”

resumen: Advantage Capital Holdings, LLC («A-CAP»), una empresa de seguros y servicios financieros con sede en Nueva York y que cuenta con más de 12 000 millones de dólares en activos, anunció que ha llevado a cabo con éxito la venta del Standard de Liège SA («Standard Liège» o el «Club»), uno de los clubes de fútbol históricos de Bélgica, así como de Immobilière du Standard de Liège SRL, la entidad corporativa propietaria del estadio del Club, el Maurice Dufrasne Stadium, a un consorcio de compradores liderado por Giacomo Angelini, director ejecutivo de Standard Liège. Esta transacción marca el final de la histórica participación de 777 Partners en el Club. Los beneficios de la transacción incluyen: mayor estabilidad en la base accionaria del Club, lo que abre la puerta a nuevas inversiones; claridad operativa, al establecer una dirección unificada que permitirá tanto a los jugadores como al plantel directivo enfocarse plenamente en el rendimiento deportivo, a la vez que garantizará que el objetivo colectivo siga siendo ganar partidos y alcanzar la excelencia a nivel deportivo, y una gestión proactiva de A-CAP, que hizo posible una transferencia ordenada de intereses, con resultados favorables para los titulares de pólizas. Kenneth King, presidente y director ejecutivo de A-CAP, señaló que esta transacción representa un logro significativo para A-CAP, el Club y sus seguidores más fieles. A-CAP ha concretado con éxito transacciones con Everton FC, Melbourne Victory FC y Standard Liège. Moelis & Company LLC se desempeñó como asesor financiero exclusivo de A-CAP en esta transacción. A-CAP es una sociedad holding que agrupa múltiples negocios de seguros y servicios financieros en una plataforma única y sinérgica. Fundada en 2013, A-CAP es una compañía privada con oficinas en Nueva York, Charleston, Miami y Salt Lake City. Standard Liège, uno de los clubes fundamentales del fútbol belga, cuenta con una larga tradición de logros destacados. El equipo masculino ha ganado 10 campeonatos de Bélgica, ocho Copas de Bélgica y cuatro Supercopas de Bélgica, mientras que el equipo femenino ha conseguido 20 campeonatos, ocho Copas y una Supercopa.

title: Editorial: Horizonte en Corea del Sur se perfila más despejado
content: En su discurso de toma de posesión, el nuevo presidente de Corea del Sur pronunció una frase que debería resonar en Costa Rica: 'La unidad es un barómetro de competencia; la división, el resultado de ...
resumen: La elección –en comicios anticipados– de un nuevo presidente pone fin a seis meses de incertidumbre y parálisis política en Corea del Sur. En su discurso de toma de posesión, Lee Jae-myung pronunció una frase que debería resonar en Costa Rica: ‘La unidad es un barómetro de competencia; la división, el resultado de la incompetencia’. La incertidumbre y virtual parálisis política que aquejaban a Corea del Sur desde diciembre concluyeron el pasado martes. En elecciones anticipadas celebradas ese día, Lee Jae-myung, del centroizquierdista Partido Democrático (PD), obtuvo 49% de los votos y se impuso sobre su principal rival, el conservador Kim Moon-soo, del Partido del Poder Popular (PPP), que recibió el 41%. El miércoles tomó posesión. Gracias a la mayoría del PD en la Asamblea Nacional, Lee tendrá un amplio margen de maniobra para hacer frente a los enormes retos que enfrenta el país. Esta vuelta a la normalidad político-institucional es una buena noticia, que trasciende el ámbito nacional e incluso regional. Costa Rica comparte con Corea estrechas afinidades en principios y acción diplomática; además, recibimos cooperación y, desde noviembre de 2019, ratificamos el tratado de libre comercio negociado con Centroamérica. La crisis política en Corea se desató el 3 de diciembre del año pasado, cuando su entonces presidente, Yoon Suk-yeol, del PPP, decretó la ley marcial, con falsas acusaciones de “traición” contra el PD. Su intentona apenas duró seis horas. La población se lanzó a las calles de la capital, Seúl, estableció un cordón de protección alrededor de su Asamblea Nacional y facilitó que sus diputados se reunieran y anularan el decreto. Siguió un juicio político y la suspensión del mandatario, quien, finalmente, fue destituido por la Corte Suprema el 4 de abril. El hecho de que, a pesar de esos antecedentes, el candidato de su partido haya recibido cuatro de cada diez votos, es una señal de las profundas divisiones en la sociedad coreana. En su discurso de toma de posesión, dejó muy clara su voluntad de hacerlo, con una frase que debería resonar en nuestro país: “La unidad es un barómetro de competencia; la división, el resultado de la incompetencia”. El nuevo mandatario, además, está ante la urgencia de dar mayor dinamismo a una economía afectada por la competencia global en sectores clave, como semiconductores, y la convulsión del comercio internacional generada por el presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump. A ello se suma el desafío social de atemperar las notables brechas generacionales y de género. Los aranceles unilaterales de Trump, junto a su exigencia de que Corea incremente sus contribuciones financieras por la presencia militar de Estados Unidos en su territorio, están en la primera línea de preocupaciones y consideraciones. Su enorme complejidad se acentúa por la necesidad de mantener, simultáneamente, buenas relaciones con China, principal rival geoeconómico estadounidense, a pesar de las presiones de Washington para que reduzca sus nexos comerciales con el gigante vecino. También será vital la orientación de las relaciones con Japón. El expresidente Yoon, estimulado por Estados Unidos, facilitó un proceso de acercamiento, que ha llevado a gran coordinación en temas de seguridad entre los tres países. El PPD, y Lee como candidato, han sido más renuentes a ella, pero ya como presidente prometió mantener, e incluso fortalecer, esa alianza, vital para la estabilidad de la zona. A lo anterior se añade un tema a la vez interno y externo: el riesgo permanente que plantea la dictadura oscurantista y dinástica de Corea del Norte, con un arsenal nuclear creciente, una modernización militar con apoyo de Rusia y una permanente actitud hostil hacia su próspero vecino. Lee abordó todos esos temas con gran sensatez en su primer mensaje como presidente, al ser investido en la Asamblea Nacional. La ruta que trazó propone una mezcla de profundo apego a la democracia, moderado cambio y apuesta a la estabilidad, el desarrollo y la seguridad. Lee Jae-myung, del centroizquierdista Partido Democrático, es el nuevo presidente de Corea del Sur.

title: ‘Could Have Gone Nuclear’: Trump Says He Averted India-Pakistan War
content: US President Donald Trump claims his administration’s intervention in 2025 averted a potential nuclear conflict between India and Pakistan by leveraging trade and diplomacy ...
resumen:
US President Donald Trump claims his administration’s intervention in 2025 averted a potential nuclear conflict between India and Pakistan by leveraging trade and diplomacy.

US President Donald Trump has claimed that his direct intervention in 2025 prevented a full-scale military conflict between India and Pakistan, which, according to him, could have escalated into a nuclear confrontation.

Trump said, speaking aboard Air Force One, “They were going at it, and it could have gone nuclear.”

He stated that he warned both nations that the United States would halt trade relations if the situation continued to spiral out of control.

The escalation between the two South Asian neighbours followed a deadly terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir’s Pahalgam area, which claimed the lives of 26 civilians.

In response, India launched “Operation Sindoor,” a significant military operation targeting terror camps across the border—its deepest known incursion since the 1971 war.

This triggered heightened military activity on both sides, leading to concerns globally that the situation could evolve into open warfare.

A ceasefire was declared on May 10, 2025, after weeks of mounting tension.

President Trump claims that it was his use of economic leverage and diplomatic communication that played a decisive role.

Trump’s remarks have sparked debate.

India has not officially commented on Trump’s statement, maintaining that all decisions regarding the ceasefire were independently reached.

The 2025 standoff stands as one of the most serious confrontations between the nuclear-armed neighbours in recent years.

title: Reino Unido en el ojo del huracán
content: Temeroso de Rusia, el Reino Unido fortalece la alianza con EEUU. Londres construirá nuevos submarinos de ataque con propulsión nuclear y creará un ejército listo para luchar en una guerra en Europa, d ...
resumen: Temeroso de Rusia, el Reino Unido fortalece la alianza con EEUU. Londres construirá nuevos submarinos de ataque con propulsión nuclear y creará un ejército listo para luchar en una guerra en Europa, dentro de un aumento en el gasto militar. El primer ministro, Keir Starmer, afirmó que Reino Unido “no puede ignorar la amenaza que representa Rusia”, mientras se comprometía a llevar a cabo los cambios más radicales en la defensa británica desde el final de la Guerra Fría hace más de tres décadas. Starmer afirmó: “Creo que la mejor forma de disuadir de un conflicto es prepararse para él”. Sus palabras fueron pronunciadas en un astillero en la ciudad escocesa de Glasgow, en el que anunció la mayor transformación e inversión militar del Reino Unido desde hace cuatro décadas. Con su discurso, el jefe del Gobierno británico señala su apoyo total a todas las propuestas incluidas en la Revisión de la Defensa Estratégica, un documento de personalidades independientes encargado por el Ministerio de Defensa, en el que se detallan esas reformas. Trump dio la bienvenida, eximiendo a Londres de la subida de aranceles al aluminio y el acero del 25% al 50%. Trump determinó que es necesario y apropiado permitir la aplicación del Acuerdo de Prosperidad Económica entre los Estados Unidos y el Reino Unido de 8 de mayo de 2025 (EPD) y, en consecuencia, conceder un trato diferente a las importaciones de artículos de acero y aluminio, y sus derivados, procedentes del Reino Unido. Los aranceles a la importación de aluminio y acero del Reino Unido “se mantendrán en el 25%”. A partir del 9 de julio de 2025, el secretario (de Comercio, Howard Lutnick), podrá aumentar los tipos de derechos aplicables al 50%, si determina que el Reino Unido no ha cumplido con los aspectos pertinentes del EPD. Trump está a punto de autorizar la venta de la empresa al grupo japonés, Nippon Steel. Trump dijo en campaña que no permitiría la venta de la compañía a Nippon Steel. Trump dijo a los trabajadores: “Hoy estamos aquí para celebrar un acuerdo trascendental que garantizará que esta histórica empresa estadounidense, siga siendo estadounidense”. Trump afirmó que esos impuestos del 50% sobre el acero importado, “asegurarán aún más la industria siderúrgica en Estados Unidos”. Trump aseguró: “Está al 25%, pueden sortear esa barrera, pero al 50% ya no podrán hacerlo”.

title: Australian military chief calls for war readiness
content: Admiral Johnston declared that Australians had to “reconsider” the country as a “homeland” from which to conduct combat operations for the first time since World War II.
resumen: Admiral David Johnston, the chief of the Australian Defence Force, issued a demand for higher military spending and the faster development of a war economy. He was responding to US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth pressing the government to raise military spending to 3.5 percent of gross domestic product (GDP). Johnston declared that Australians had to “reconsider” the country as a “homeland” from which to conduct combat operations for the first time since World War II. Hegseth laid down the law to governments throughout the region at last weekend’s Shangri-la Dialogue, demanding they escalate their military build-up for “imminent” conflict with China. Hegseth announced he had “conveyed” to the Australian Labor government that it should increase its military spending from around 2 percent to 3.5 percent of GDP “as soon as possible.” Johnston spoke at a conference hosted by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI). Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has not committed his government to meeting Hegseth’s demand, yet he has emphasized Labor’s readiness to further raise the military budget. Johnston told the ASPI conference that, in preparing the government’s 2026 National Defence Strategy: “It’s my job and that of the department to give government that frank advice and a view of what we need to be doing.” The 2024 National Defence Strategy declared that Australia faced the “most challenging strategic environment” since World War II and the end of a 10-year strategic warning time for conflict, naming China as the central target. It called for a “whole-of-government and whole-of-nation approach.” The 2024 document was based on Labor’s 2023 Defence Strategic Review. Johnston outlined a total reorganisation of the continent. He listed challenges facing the “northern infrastructure” including limited fuel storage, long supply lines, a lack of adequate medical facilities, and an absence of industry capable of rapidly repairing equipment damaged in battle. The ABC’s David Speers commented: “It all sounded rather similar to the ‘war-fighting readiness’ Sir Keir Starmer spoke of in the UK.” At the Shangri-La Dialogue, Hegseth also pushed for “an integrated defense industrial base” to support a US-led war against China. Labor’s 2024 National Defence Strategy committed the Albanese government to continuing to militarise the north of the Australian continent. This includes greater access to ports and air and army bases, the $368 billion acquisition of AUKUS nuclear-powered submarines, more frequent visits by US nuclear submarines, fuel storage capabilities for long-range US bombers, the rotational presence of 2,500 US marines near Darwin and expansions to the Pine Gap satellite surveillance station in central Australia.

title: Corporate Media Thought They Had Trump On Ropes Over Egg Prices — It Quickly Blew Up In Their Faces
content: The corporate media believed they had President Donald Trump trapped in a corner when it came to rising egg prices, ...
resumen: The corporate media believed they had President Donald Trump trapped in a corner when it came to rising egg prices, but the costs of eggs soon dropped dramatically. Despite the media’s groaning, the price of eggs dropped over 61% since Trump took office on January 20, which went down significantly from an all-time high cost of $8 a dozen in the first week of March. The average cost of eggs amounted to $6.41 on Jan. 21, Trump’s first full day of his second term, and that number currently stands at $2.57 as of Friday, according to Trade Economics. In an attempt to shift criticism from former President Joe Biden to Trump regarding egg prices, corporate media outlets highlighted expensive egg prices, tried to fact-check Trump’s statements on prices and repeatedly predicted that Trump would never be able to bring down the costs. The Associated Press wrote on March 7 that the Democrats believed that rising egg prices were their “road to recovery.” It noted that the Department of Agriculture expected egg prices to go up by 41% in 2025, and quoted Democrats pinning the rising prices on Trump. PBS News also published an April 10 article titled, “Egg prices increase to record high despite Trump promises and curbing bird flu outbreak,” which attempted to claim that Trump did not uphold his promises to lower egg prices. In February, The New York Times published the headline, “Inflation Is Trump’s Problem Now,” which claimed that Trump inherited a “strong economy” and would have to “contend” with rising egg prices due to bird flu. It quoted Jeffrey Roach, chief economist at LPL Financial, stating that the rise in egg prices was the “largest increase in roughly a decade.” Several outlets attempted to “fact-check” Trump as he touted the prices of eggs coming down. The Times continued to try and highlight the egg prices under Trump even when they dropped by more than half of a percent within just a few months of his second term. Linda Qiu, a reporter for the Times, wrote that the wholesale price of eggs were not yet “reflected” in the retail price, making consumers still pay high prices for eggs. CBS News and CNN both accused Trump in April of lying about the rapid decrease in prices. CNN claimed on April 23 that Trump lied when he touted that the wholesale cost of eggs had gone down by 94% since he began his second term. In a separate article, CNN claimed on Feb. 27 that while Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins provided a detailed plan to lower egg prices, the outlet argued that American consumers should not “expect relief” on egg prices. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins laid out her “comprehensive strategy” to lower egg prices in a Feb. 26 op-ed in The Wall Street Journal. Her five-step plan included dedicating $500 million to help poultry farmers with biosecurity measures, provide millions more in financial relief for farmers impacted by the avian flu, research vaccinations and therapeutics for egg-laying chickens, remove unnecessary regulations on egg producers and temporarily import eggs from other countries. As egg prices began to drop, NBC News claimed that grocery shoppers were bracing to pay more for eggs and other food items. A Reuters article from April 3 suggested that Trump’s tariffs would cause egg prices to soar just as they started decreasing from record-high levels. USA Today columnist Rex Huppke published an op-ed on April 19 claiming that Trump “ruined Easter with his astronomical egg prices.” The op-ed claimed that the president “failed” to lower egg prices, had lied about egg prices going down and made prices soar even more from his tariffs. “The View” co-host Whoopi Goldberg falsely claimed during an April 9 segment that egg prices had not fallen by “one cent” since Trump took office, though in reality, the costs of eggs had fallen 44% at the time since the start of 2025. Over at MSNBC, “Morning Joe” host Joe Scarborough claimed during a March 7 segment that egg prices were going up under Trump’s watch. CNN host Abby Phillip aired a fact-checking segment for Trump on April 23 as he said that the “cost of eggs has come down like 93, 94%,” though she still had to admit that egg prices had fallen despite Trump having exaggerated the numbers. CNN fact-checker Daniel Dale also emphasized that Trump exaggerated how much egg prices had dropped, and said that egg prices had risen to a “record-high” during an April 24 segment of “The Lead.” MSNBC’s Ari Melber highlighted how Trump vowed to lower prices, including the cost of eggs, at the beginning of his term, but gleefully claimed that Trump had failed to fulfill that promise during a Feb. 25 segment.

title: La relación de China con América Latina Entre «embates y chantajes» de Trump
content: Madrid, 6 Jun (Sputnik).- Como "excelente" tildó el presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, la conversación telefónica que tuvo el jueves con su homólogo de China, Xi Jinping. "Se centró casi exclusivamen ...
resumen:
El presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, tildó de "excelente" la conversación telefónica que tuvo con su homólogo de China, Xi Jinping, que se centró casi exclusivamente en el comercio, un ámbito en el que ambas potencias se disputan América Latina.

Según un documento reciente de la Comisión Económica para América Latina y el Caribe (Cepal), el Acuerdo de Asociación Transpacífico firmado en febrero de 2016 por EE.UU. para contrarrestar la competencia de China, "puede considerarse el origen de las tensiones comerciales entre ambas grandes economías".

Washington se salió del pacto antes de su entrada en vigor y "optó por enfrentar unilateralmente el reto que plantea China". Era la época del primer mandato de Trump, la primera versión de la guerra comercial con Pekín.

En 2025, con el regreso de Trump a la Casa Blanca, las tensiones arancelarias han retornado. Mientras tanto, China ha incrementado su presencia económica en la región, incluso institucionalizándola con instrumentos como la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta.

El comercio de bienes de la región con China aumentó del 1,7 % en 2000 al 17 % en 2023, consolidando a China desde 2019 como el segundo socio comercial de la región y uno de sus principales motores de crecimiento. Números que contrastan con la reducción del intercambio con EE.UU., que pasó del 54 % en 2000 al 37 % en 2023, anotó la Cepal.

En sus discursos, Xi suele aludir constantemente al concepto de nueva era. En diciembre pasado durante el primer foro legal entre China y los países miembros de la Comunidad de Estados Latinoamericanos y Caribeños (Celac), se abogó por un compromiso más profundo en este campo a través de la cooperación jurídica.

El coordinador del Centro de Estudios China-México (Cechimex) de la Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México (UNAM), Enrique Dussel Peters, estima que en el siglo XXI, la presencia china ha crecido en forma muy significativa, en términos cualitativos.

Desde hace 50 años aproximadamente, Latinoamérica se relaciona con Pekín, pero en ese momento era un nexo mayormente político, abocado al reconocimiento de la República Popular China, del principio de una sola China.

Muchos especialistas han escrito que la teoría de ‘patio trasero’ establecida en asentamientos de poder en Washington, ha provocado que la región quede en segundo o tercer plano. Caso contrario al chino que, en busca de nuevos mercados para sus ingentes exportaciones, expandió su mirada comercial.

El IV Foro Ministerial China-Celac en Pekín, uno de los aliados históricos de EE.UU., Perú, animó a Washington a competir en igualdad ante China, que ya es su principal socio comercial.

El canciller peruano, Elmer Schialer, comentó que es legítimo que los países de América Latina busquen en el mundo socios estratégicos para su desarrollo.

Dussel dice que lo que se está viviendo es una confrontación entre las dos principales economías, China y EE.UU., y terceras partes que pueden ser regiones, América Latina y el Caribe.

El experto resalta el IV Foro Ministerial China-Celac, al que asistieron los mandatarios Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, de Brasil; Gustavo Petro, de Colombia; y Gabriel Boric, de Chile, como un espacio "para contrarrestar los embates y chantajes de Donald Trump".

Dussel destaca que el lenguaje de cooperación, de respeto mutuo, de que los países son iguales, es un lenguaje muy diferente a las órdenes ejecutivas.

El lema de Trump es ‘America First’ [‘EE.UU. primero’, en inglés].

Tanto medios como analistas han considerado que China le ha ganado la partida a EE.UU. en el ámbito latinoamericano. Dussel no lo tiene tan claro.

Dussel menciona el caso de México, que tiene más de 3.000 kilómetros de frontera y hay cientos de temas, de migración a fentanilo, a inversiones y una cantidad de temas que habrá que negociar de alguna forma.

Schialer afirmó que la política exterior que llevan adelante es de una neutralidad constructiva, es decir, van a abrir las puertas a todos los países amigos y aliados que quieran colaborar conjuntamente en crear riqueza.

América Latina y cada uno de sus países tendrá que tomar una decisión pragmática con respecto a cientos de temas, a las 6G, a inversiones, a turismo, a infraestructura, a cultura, a cooperación, a intercambio, a ciencia y tecnología.

En opinión de Dussel, la hesitación actual es aranceles o cooperación.

title: US Growth Likely To Slow To 1.6% This Year, Hobbled By Trump’s Trade Wars, OECD Says
content: U.S. economic growth will slow to 1.6% this year from 2.8% last year as President Donald Trump’s erratic trade wars disrupt global commerce, drive up costs and leave businesses and consumers paralyzed ...
resumen: U.S. economic growth will slow to 1.6% this year from 2.8% last year. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) forecast Tuesday that the U.S. economy will slow further to just 1.5% in 2026. Trump’s policies have raised average U.S. tariff rates from around 2.5% when he returned to the White House to 15.4%, highest since 1938, according to the OECD. World economic growth will slow to just 2.9% this year and stay there in 2026, according to the OECD’s forecast. Global growth was 3.3% last year and 3.4% in 2023. Trump has levied 10% taxes — tariffs — on imports from almost every country on earth along with specific duties on steel, aluminum and autos. He’s also threatened more import taxes, including a doubling of his tariffs on steel and aluminum to 50%. OECD chief economist Álvaro Pereira wrote in a commentary that accompanied the forecast that “we have seen a significant increase in trade barriers as well as in economic and trade policy uncertainty. China — the world’s second-biggest economy — is forecast to see growth decelerate from 5% last year to 4.7% in 2025 and 4.3% in 2026. The 20 countries that share the euro currency will collectively see economic growth pick up from 0.8% last year to 1% in 2025 and 1.2% next year, the OECD said. title: China’s earth weapon changes trade war battlefield
content: The scramble in recent weeks to secure export licences for rare earths, capped by Thursday’s telephone call between U.S. and Chinese leaders Donald Trump and Xi Jinping, shows China has devised a ...
resumen: China has signaled for more than 15 years that it was looking to weaponize areas of the global supply chain. The scramble in recent weeks to secure export licences for rare earths shows China has devised a better, more precisely targeted weapon for a trade war. China’s export licence system gives it unprecedented insight into supplier chokepoints in areas ranging from motors for electric vehicles to flight-control systems for guided missiles. China has been trying to build its own export control systems since then, to be used as a last resort. After a call between U.S. and Chinese leaders, Trump said both leaders had been “straightening out some of the points, having to do mostly with rare earth magnets and some other things”. China holds a near-monopoly on rare earth magnets, a crucial component in EV motors. In April, it added some of the most sophisticated types to an export control list in its trade war with the United States, forcing all exporters to apply to Beijing for licences. Several European auto suppliers shut down production lines this week after running out of supplies. Beijing’s measures apply globally. China mines about 70% of the world’s rare earths but has a virtual monopoly on refining and processing. The new system gives Beijing unprecedented glimpses of how companies in a supply chain deploy the rare earths it processes. Hundreds of Japanese suppliers are believed to need China to approve export licences for rare earth magnets in coming weeks to avert production disruptions.

content: The National Fire Authority responded swiftly to a fire that broke out early this morning at a vacant building located on Amy Street, opposite the Colonial War Memorial Hospital morgue in Suva.

title: Trump shows that loyalty is all that matters to him
content: Last week, the Court of International Trade delivered a blow to Donald Trump’s global trade war. It found that the worldwide tariffs Trump unveiled on “Liberation Day” as well his earlier tariffs ...
resumen: Last week, the Court of International Trade delivered a blow to Donald Trump’s global trade war. It found that the worldwide tariffs Trump unveiled on “Liberation Day” as well his earlier tariffs pretextually aimed at stopping fentanyl coming in from Mexico and Canada were beyond his authority. The three-judge panel was surely right about the Liberation Day tariffs and probably right about the fentanyl tariffs. Trump cannot conceive of a good explanation for an inconvenient court ruling other than Trump Derangement Syndrome. The decision was unanimous and only one of the three judges was appointed by Trump (the other two were Reagan and Obama appointees). (The decision has been paused by an appeals court.). Trump is the foremost practitioner of what I call Critical Trump Theory — anything bad for Trump is unfair, illegitimate and proof that sinister forces are rigging the system against him. Trump thinks Leonard Leo, formerly a guiding light at the Federalist Society, is a “sleazebag” and “bad person.” Congress is AWOL, refusing to take the lead on trade (and many other things) as the Constitution envisions, it’s fallen to the courts to restrain Trump’s multifront efforts to exceed his authority. The supreme, and sometimes seemingly sole, qualification for appointments to the Trump administration has been servile loyalty to Trump. Trump has a history of suggesting “my judges” — i.e., his appointees — should be loyal to him. He recently nominated Emil Bove, his former personal criminal lawyer turned political enforcer at the Department of Justice, for a federal judgeship. The legal movement spearheaded by the Federalist Society has been the most successful domestic conservative project of the last century. Trump has issued a fatwa that it, too, must bend the knee and its principles to the needs of one man. In 2016, the death of Antonin Scalia left a vacancy on the Supreme Court. Trump agreed to pick from a list of potential replacements crafted by the Heritage Foundation and Federalist Society. The Heritage Foundation has dutifully reinvented itself in Trump’s image. The Federalist Society stayed loyal to its principles, and that’s why the Federalist Society is in Trump’s crosshairs.

title: Las ventas crecieron en el primer trimestre de 2025 en Ecuador
content: El comercio al por mayor y menor y la reparación de vehículos y motocicletas son los sectores que más ventas alcanzaron entre enero y marzo de este año, seguidos de industrias manufactureras y agricul ...
resumen: Las ventas crecieron en el primer trimestre de 2025 en Ecuador. Casi USD 57 mil millones se vendieron en el primer trimestre del año, en Ecuador. El comercio al por mayor y menor y la reparación de vehículos y motocicletas son los sectores que más ventas alcanzaron entre enero y marzo de este año, seguidos de industrias manufactureras y agricultura, según un informe del Observatorio de economía de la Cámara de Comercio de Quito. El Servicio de Rentas Internas, SRI, informó que en el primer trimestre de 2025 el monto de ventas en el país llegó a USD 56 903 millones que implica un 7,5 % de incremento respecto del mismo periodo en 2024. Quito es el cantón donde más ventas se registraron señala el informe del Observatorio, 17 mil millones sin contar exportaciones, Guayaquil llegó a 12 mil millones y el tercero es Cuenca con USD 1 965 millones. El comercio es donde existe el mayor movimiento económico USD 21 mil 585 millones corresponden a ese sector en este primer trimestre, mil millones más que en el mismo periodo del año pasado. Este sector tiene a dos de las más grandes corporaciones de supermercados en el top 5 de las más ventas en 2024, de acuerdo al ranking publicado por la Superintendencia de Compañías. Las actividades de atención de salud y asistencia social son las de mayor crecimiento en porcentaje, mientras quienes han decaído son sectores como la construcción y la explotación de minas y canteras.

title: Trump y Musk: el fin de un “bromance” de alto voltaje
content: Durante meses, Elon Musk caminó por los pasillos del poder en Estados Unidos como si fueran suyos, desatando despidos masivos, recortando ...
resumen:
El romance político entre Elon Musk y Donald Trump parece haber llegado a su fin. Lo que alguna vez fue una alianza estratégica entre dos multimillonarios, se desmoronó en público con acusaciones incendiarias. Musk ahora coquetea con la idea de un tercer partido, mientras Trump refuerza su trinchera.

Durante meses, Elon Musk fue una figura influyente en el segundo mandato de Donald Trump. Trump le entregó las llaves de la Casa Blanca. La alianza entre ambos terminó en un campo de batalla que reconfigura el mapa de poder de la derecha estadounidense.

Elon Musk invirtió más de 275 millones de dólares en la campaña electoral trumpista de 2024. Musk fue apodado "el primer amigo". La relación llegó a su apogeo después del atentado contra Trump en julio del mismo año. Trump le otorgó a Musk el mando del Departamento de Eficiencia Gubernamental (DOGE).

El regreso de Donald Trump a la presidencia trajo consigo un endurecimiento de la política económica, afectando a Tesla. Las acciones de Tesla cayeron más del 35% en semanas recientes, arrastrando la fortuna de Musk.

El primer punto de quiebre entre Trump y Musk fue cuando Musk abandonó la Casa Blanca en abril de 2025. Musk tuvo una pelea a gritos con el secretario del Tesoro, John Bessent. La verdadera manzana de la discordia llegó porque en la gira de Trump por los países árabes se dio un gran contrato a la empresa de Inteligencia Artificial OpenAI, a la que Musk percibe como acérrima competidora.

El detonante público fue el proyecto de ley de gasto interno, que Musk criticó, refiriéndose a ella como una "abominación repugnante". Musk escribió: "Sin mí, Trump habría perdido las elecciones. Qué ingratitud". Trump respondió: "Elon estaba agotado. Le pedí que se fuera. Le retiré su estúpido Mandato de Vehículos Eléctricos. ¡Y se volvió loco!".

Trump comenzó a aludir a recortes de contratos millonarios con las empresas de Musk. Musk dejó entrever amenazas veladas y abiertas: "Trump está en los archivos de Epstein".

Musk lanzó una encuesta en su plataforma X preguntando a sus seguidores si sería conveniente fundar un tercer partido político. El sondeo rozaba los 3,5 millones de votos, con un abrumador apoyo de ocho de cada diez votantes a la creaciÃ³n de esa nueva alternativa.

Según personas cercanas a su entorno, el CEO de Tesla y SpaceX había estado consumiendo drogas. Su comportamiento errático en la Casa Blanca alarmó incluso a sus más fieles defensores.

Musk tiene catorce hijos reconocidos, relaciones sentimentales simultáneas y batallas legales con exparejas.

Musk ha amenazado con desmantelar la nave espacial Dragon de SpaceX. Trump baraja retirar todos los contratos federales vigentes con las empresas del magnate y presionar para que se inicien investigaciones legales contra él.

Uno de los más feroces opositores de Musk dentro del círculo trumpista es Stephen Bannon, quien ha aconsejado cancelar todos los contratos públicos.

Musk había prometido donar 100 millones de dólares para las elecciones de medio término de 2026.

resumen:
Wall Street cerró la semana con ganancias acumuladas de más del 2 % en el Nasdaq y en torno al 1 % en el Dow Jones y el S&P 500 tras unos datos de empleo mejores de lo esperado en EE.UU. y avances en materia comercial con China.

La sesión de este viernes terminó con subidas del 1% en el Dow Jones (hasta 42.762 puntos) y el S&P 500 (6.000 puntos) y del 1,2% en el Nasdaq (19.529 puntos).

El informe de empleo de mayo en EE.UU., divulgado hoy por el Gobierno, fue el colofón positivo a la semana, ya que la tasa de paro se mantuvo en el 4,2 %, el mismo nivel que en abril y marzo, con una creación de 139.000 nuevos puestos.

Las solicitudes de subsidio por desempleo habían aumentado más de lo esperado por los analistas, 8.000 en una semana, y el sector privado estadounidense creó menos puestos en mayo de los esperados, lo que había generado preocupación.

Los analistas de Wells Fargo recordaron hoy que “los altos aranceles han revivido los temores por la inflación” y señalaron que los datos en general apuntan “al debilitamiento de las condiciones de empleo” por lo que esperan que la Fed recorte los tipos a finales de año.

En el plano comercial, el mercado se animó ante la llamada entre el presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, y su homólogo chino, Xi Jinping, de este jueves, y se espera que el lunes continúen las conversaciones sobre aranceles a alto nivel en la ciudad de Londres.

La semana comenzó con las acusaciones mutuas de Washington y Pekín sobre su supuesto incumplimiento del acuerdo alcanzado en mayo para reducir temporalmente los aranceles bilaterales.

El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump anunció el viernes una nueva ronda de conversaciones comerciales con China la próxima semana en Londres.
El encuentro entre ambas comitivas ocurrirá el lunes 9 de junio.
Las conversaciones del lunes marcarán la segunda ronda de las negociaciones entre las dos economías más grandes del mundo desde que Trump lanzó su guerra comercial este año.
La delegación estadounidense estará encabezada por el secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent; el titular de Comercio, Howard Lutnick y el representante comercial, Jamieson Greer.
En abril, los aranceles adicionales de Estados Unidos sobre muchos productos chinos alcanzaron un 145%, mientras que China respondió con contramedidas del 125%.
Tras las conversaciones del mes pasado, ambas partes acordaron reducir temporalmente los gravámenes: los de Estados Unidos bajaron al 30% y los de China, al 10%.
Se espera que esta pausa expire a principios de agosto.

title: China's e-commerce sellers say Trump's tariffs have been a 'rollercoaster' ride
content: Marketplace has been following Lei’s business since 2018, just before President Trump imposed tariffs in his first term. Not only did his business survive the extra levies, but Lei said the percentage ...
resumen:
China’s e-commerce sellers say Trump's tariffs have been a 'rollercoaster' ride.

Shanghai’s Vicky Su, 31, sells a mix of products on Amazon including toys, boxer briefs and Japanese futon covers. She has kept overheads low by having her parents help and shipping products duty-free to the U.S. under the de minimis exemption.

The de minimis policy allowed items valued at $800 or less to be imported tax-free.

Trump ended the duty-free loophole for Chinese goods on May 2.

The first time he canceled the de minimis exemption was in early February, and he hiked tariffs on all Chinese exports to 10%.

The U.S. Postal Service suspended parcels from China and Hong Kong the following day.

Another e-commerce seller, lingerie manufacturer Lei Congrui, manufactures sheer dresses and other costumes. He sold direct to customers through de minimis, and as a wholesaler.

Lei said the percentage of his sales to the U.S. went up from 50% in 2018 to 70% at the start of this year.

A day after Marketplace spoke to both sellers in February, the USPS reversed course and started accepting parcels from China again. Trump also reinstated the de minimis exemption temporarily.

In February, Su had about 200 orders a day from the U.S. That changed in May, when Trump officially cancelled the de minimis exemption for China and imposed sky-high tariffs of 145% on most Chinese exports.

The U.S. set a separate and slightly lower tariff of 120% on small parcels coming from China or a flat fee of $100 per package.

When Marketplace checked in with Su in May, she said she had no choice but to raise prices and it has hurt business. Her orders have dropped by 60% to 70%.

Lei’s wholesale business is fine for now because he’s stocked up on pre-tariff products in his U.S. warehouse. However, Trump’s punitive levies killed a lot of orders on his direct-to-consumer sales.

On May 12, the U.S. and China had a truce of sorts. The two countries announced in Geneva a 90-day reduction in tariffs as they hammer out a trade deal.

The U.S. tariff on overall Chinese exports was cut from an extra 145% to 30%, plus any pre-existing duties. While an additional duty on small parcels was cut from 120% to 54%.

China dropped tariffs on all American exports from 125% to 10%. This is on top of the 10% to 15% retaliatory duties on certain American exports such as coal and agricultural products, and non-tariff measures such as export restrictions on minerals essential for high-tech products.
